section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce children to each other, build math background, and introduce vocabulary (number, calendar)
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, Where can we find numbers?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, pointing out uses and meanings of numbers.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that items and amounts can be counted.
Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Use pretend money during play, earning money for work, and using money to buy goods and services.
Knows the purpose of common measuring tools.
Express pride in age-appropriate skills.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Introduce children to Number Cards and Two-Color counters.
Guide children to count to 10.
Help children count up to three counters.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Are there numbers in your book? What are they used for?
How do you use numbers while you are playing store?
What can you count in this center?
Draw or write about numbers.
Can you make a number with those materials? What number did you make?
Can you count how many letters are in your name? What are the letters?
Can you make a tower with five blocks? What about seven blocks?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to learn about self-awareness and pride, and to introduce vocabulary (proud, temperature).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to I Know Numbers!.
Read closely to notice measuring tools and uses of numbers, and to share personal information, showing self-awareness.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that items and amounts can be counted.
Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time.
Know the purpose of common measuring tools.
Express pride in age appropriate skills.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to join a “number band” to practice counting from 1–10.
Challenge children to add the next number to the number “song.”
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Do you hear any numbers in the book? Show me which ones.
Act like you are shopping at the store. What will you buy with this pretend money?
What do numbers tell you on the measuring tools?
Show a person using numbers in their daily life.
Can you make a number out of these materials?
How many letters are in your first name?
Use blocks to build a number.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. I Know Numbers! by Taro Gomi. Copyright © 1985 by Taro Gomi. Translation copyright © 2017 by Chronicle Books LLC. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Chronicle Books LLC. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to identify numbers, play a counting game, and introduce vocabulary (weight, price).
Begin Story Time by revisiting I Know Numbers! and asking the guiding question, What are numbers used for?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to practice counting.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that items and amounts can be counted.
Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time.
Know the purpose of common measuring tools.
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Explore geography tools and resources such as maps, signs, and street addresses.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Show picture cards, name the objects, and think about how much items weigh.
Guide children to order the cards from lightest to heaviest objects.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What are the names of the people in the book?
Pretend you’re at a store. What store are you at? Why do you need to go to that store?
Which of these objects is heavier? How can you tell?
What is your favorite number? Can you write about it?
Why did you decide to make that? Tell me about it.
How do you spell your name?
Why did you decide to build that? How could you make that building taller?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. I Know Numbers! by Taro Gomi. Copyright © 1985 by Taro Gomi. Translation copyright © 2017 by Chronicle Books LLC. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Chronicle Books LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: I like to...

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about activities children like and introduce vocabulary (square, catch).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts I like to... and I Know Numbers.
Read closely to connect to this week’s essential question, What makes us who we are?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that items and amounts can be counted.
Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall” and “long.”

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Express pride in age-appropriate skills.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Write for different purposes.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to compare the sizes of Connecting Cube towers.
Help children discuss how they know which tower is taller and which tower is shorter.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Choose an object in your book. How could you measure it?
Pretend you are playing a sport. How do you score? How do you know who wins?
Measure two objects. Which is bigger? How do you know?
Compare two numbers. Which is greater? Which is lesser? How do you know?
What is the best part of your creation?
Put these letters in the order of the alphabet.
How many different blocks are you using? Count them. Can you use more blocks? Fewer?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. I Know Numbers! by Taro Gomi. Copyright © 1985 by Taro Gomi. Translation copyright © 2017 by Chronicle Books LLC. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Chronicle Books LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to celebrate the end of the first week of school, do a number scavenger hunt, and introduce vocabulary (size, score).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What is one way you use numbers every day?
Reread and reenact the story for physical engagement and imagination, focusing on counting and measurement.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that items and amounts can be counted.
Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time.
Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long.”
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Express pride in age appropriate abilities and skills.
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Compose a narrative.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Where do you find numbers at school?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you imagine what might happen next in that book?
Can you think of a pretend number?
Can you make this group have more than this group?
What story can you tell about the biggest number you know?
Can you create a fun poster about your favorite number?
Write all of the numbers you know.
Use blocks to create a building. What number will you use for its address?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Know that objects, or parts of an object, can be counted.
Use words to rote count from 1 to 30.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age appropriate abilities and skills.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Explore geography tools and resources.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Know that objects, or parts of objects, can be counted.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age appropriate abilities and skills.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Explore geography tools and resources.
Know that objects, or parts of an object, can be counted.
Use words to rote count from 1 to 30.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age appropriate abilities and skills.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Explore geography tools and resources.
Know that objects, or parts of an object, can be counted.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age appropriate abilities and skills
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Know that objects, or parts of an object, can be counted.
Use words to rote count from 1 to 30.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age appropriate abilities and skills.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
